Graphical abstract Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts were synthesized using a precipitation method and their catalytic activities for NO selective reduction with NH3 at low temperatures were evaluated. Nb doping not only improved the activity of the catalyst over a wide temperature range but also restricted the generation of NO2 and N2O. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst displayed 100% NO conversion from 150 to 250°C and >90% N2 selectivity below 250°C. The specific surface area of the catalyst was increased and its surface acidity was strengthened after Nb doping. Moreover, Nb doping increased the NO oxidation ability and lowered the NH3 oxidation activity of the catalyst. All the above factors contributed to enhancing the overall NH3-SCR performance of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst compared with that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one. The long-term stability and resistance to H2O and SO2 of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst were also evaluated. Keywords Low-temperature SCR Nb modification Acid sites N2 selectivity H2O and SO2 resistance 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO and NO2) originating from the combustion process are major air pollutants that can cause ozone depletion, urban smog, and acid rain [1–4]. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x by NH3 using V2O5/WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts is the most efficient method to reduce the NO x components from a stationary source developed to date. However, this kind of catalyst must be located upstream to guarantee its suitable temperature range (300–400°C) and some problems still exist, including the volatility and harmfulness of vanadium [5], the loss of activity at high concentrations of SO2, and ash in the flue gas [6,7]. Thus, there has been strong interest in developing environmentally friendly and highly active catalysts for the low-temperature (140–200°C) SCR process. Such catalysts can be placed after the desulfurizer and electrostatic precipitator to avoid deactivation by sulfur and dust [6,8]. Compared with V2O5/WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts, Mn-based catalysts, such as MnO x [9–11], MnO x /TiO2 [2,6,8,12–21], MnO x -CeO2 mixed oxides [1,22,23], and MnO x /zeolite (NaY, USY, SBA-15, ZSM-5, etc.) [14,24–26], are more efficient in the SCR process below 300°C. Among the various Mn-based catalysts mentioned above, the MnO x /TiO2 catalysts are the most widely studied. Smirniotis et al. [8] compared the NH3-SCR activity of different metal oxides (VO x , CrO x , MnO x , NiO x, and CuO x ) loaded onto various supports (Hombikat-TiO2, SiO2, and γ-Al2O3) and found that the MnO x /TiO2 catalyst exhibited the best performance. Ettireddy et al. [13] synthesized a series of catalysts in which MnO x was supported on TiO2 using a wet impregnation method to investigate the effects of TiO2 supports and MnO x loadings on catalytic performance. The best catalyst in their study achieved 94% NO conversion at 175°C with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50,000h−1. CeO2 is commonly used to modify NH3-SCR catalysts because of its high oxygen mobility [27–29]. Boningari and co-workers [30] investigated a Ce-modified MnO x /TiO2 catalyst in the SCR reaction; they found that the distribution and concentration of the acid sites could be considerably improved by co-loading Mn and Ce onto TiO2, which increased catalytic activity in the SCR reaction. Kwon et al. [19,31] used W to modify the MnO x /CeO2/TiO2 system, increasing the number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, active sites, and oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. They optimized the W content to enhance the NH3-SCR activity of the W-doped MnO x -CeO2-TiO2 catalyst. Nb is another commonly used promoter in SCR catalysts, including MnO x , FeO x , Ce x Zr1-x O y , VO x /TiO2, and VO x /CeO2 catalysts [22,32–35]. The introduction of Nb can not only improve the physicochemical properties of the catalysts, such as increasing specific surface area and tuning redox abilities, but also promote the adsorption and activation of the reactants. In our previous studies, Nb was used as a comparative element with W, which increased both the catalytic activity and N2 selectivity of MnO x -CeO2 mixed oxide catalysts for NH3-SCR [36]. It is possible that Nb will also have positive effects on the MnO x /CeO2/TiO2 catalyst system. In the present study, we synthesized Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts by a precipitation method and determined their performance in the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. The promotion effects of Nb on NO conversion and N2 selectivity were investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts were synthesized using a precipitation method. For the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, 3g of TiO2 (Alfa Aesar, United States) passed through a 100-mesh sieve was added as the catalyst support into an aqueous solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.5%, Aladdin, China) and Mn(NO3)2 (50% solution, Aladdin, China); the molar ratio of Mn/Ce/Ti was 4:4:10. An excess of aqueous urea solution was then added. The solution was vigorously stirred for 4h at 90°C to produce a homogeneous suspension. The pH of the solution during the precipitation process was kept at ∼10. Then, H2O2 solution was added to the suspension dropwise and it was stirred for another 1h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water, dried in an oven at 110°C overnight, and then calcined at 500°C for 4h in static air. To prepare the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst with an atomic molar ratio of 4:4:1:10, C10H5NbO20 (99.5%, Wengjiang, China) was first dissolved in HNO3 solution and heated to remove the oxalic ions. Then, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Mn(NO3)2 were added to form a homogeneous solution. The subsequent steps were the same as those followed to prepare the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. 2.2 Catalytic activity tests The NH3-SCR activities of the catalysts were evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor (i.d. 6mm) at temperatures from 25 to 300°C in increments of 25°C under atmospheric pressure. Each catalyst was pressed, crushed, and passed through a 50–80-mesh sieve before 200mg of the catalyst was put into the reactor. The reactant gas mixture consisted of 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3, and 5 vol% O2 balanced by N2 with a total flow rate of 500mLmin−1 and a GHSV of 180,000h−1. Before each test, the catalyst was pretreated with 5% O2/N2 at 300°C for 30min. The effluent gas after the reaction, which included NH3, NO, N2O, and NO2, was continuously detected by a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (MKS Multigas™ 2030 gas-phase, United States) with a spectral resolution of 0.5cm−1. The NO conversion (NOconv.), NH3 conversion (NH3conv.), and N2 selectivity (N2selec.) after the reaction was stable for 20min at each temperature point were calculated according to Formulas (1), (2), and (3), respectively, as follows [21,37]: (1) N O conv . ( % ) = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % (2) N H 3 conv. ( % ) = [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 % (3) N 2 selec. ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 % To investigate the long-term reaction and effects of H2O (5 vol%) and SO2 (100ppm) on the performance of the catalyst, we selected 175°C as the reaction temperature to reflect the actual application conditions for the low-temperature SCR. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The bulk compositions of the mixed oxide catalysts were measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES; Vista-MPX, Varian, United States). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) using Cu K α radiation (λ=0.15418nm) with the X-ray tube operated at 300mA and 40kV. Diffraction patterns were recorded between 10° and 80° at a scan rate of 6°min−1 and interval of 0.02°. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms recorded at −196°C on a JW-BK122F analyzer (Beijing JWGB, China). Prior to N2 adsorption, the samples were outgassed for 2.5h at 220°C to desorb moisture adsorbed on their surfaces and inside their porous networks. Specific surface areas and pore volumes were calculated according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. The morphologies of the catalysts were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JSM-7001F, JEOL) with an accelerating voltage of 30kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed under ultrahigh vacuum (1.33×10−8 Pa) conditions on an electron spectrometer (PHI-5300, ESCA) equipped with an Al Kα (hv =1486.6eV) radiation source. After being pretreated in 10% O2/N2 (50mLmin−1) at 300°C for 30min, the catalyst was mounted onto the sample holder and the chamber was degassed to the required vacuum conditions. The binding energies (BE) of the different elements were calibrated internally using the BE of carbon C1 s at 284.8eV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were performed on a chemisorption system (Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920). For each experiment, catalyst (∼50mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube and pretreated in 10% O2/N2 (50mLmin−1) at 300°C for 30min. The temperature was cooled to 0°C, and then He was introduced into the reactor to purge any weakly chemisorbed oxygen species. The catalyst was then reduced in a flow of 10% H2/Ar (50mLmin−1) from 0 to 1000°C. At the same time, the signal was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector. The H2 consumption was quantitatively calculated based on calibration runs using a standard silver oxide sample (Micromeritics) in place of the catalyst. Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) measurements were conducted using the same instrument as the activity measurement and the signal was detected by a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Co., Ltd., Oministar 200). Catalyst (200mg) was pretreated with 20% O2/N2 at 300°C for 60min and then cooled to room temperature. The residual O2 was purged with pure N2. The temperature was ramped from room temperature to 900°C and the O2 signal was recorded. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), NH3 oxidation, and NO oxidation measurements were performed using the same instrument with the same amount and pretreatment procedures as employed for the NH3-SCR activity tests. For NH3-TPD, the pretreated catalyst was exposed to 500ppm NH3 balanced with N2 for 1h to ensure the adsorption sites were saturated with NH3. N2 was used to purge the catalyst for another 1h to desorb the weakly adsorbed NH3. Finally, the temperature was raised to 400°C at a ramp rate of 10°Cmin−1 in N2 flow (total flow rate of 425mLmin−1) and the concentrations of the products were recorded. For the NH3 oxidation and NO oxidation experiments, gas mixtures of 500ppm NH3 or 500ppm NO, respectively, with 5% O2 in N2 (total flow rate of 500mLmin−1) were used. The NH3 and NO conversions were calculated using the formulas in Section 2.2. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst structure and morphology The chemical compositions of the catalysts were measured by ICP-AES and the weight percentage of each element in the catalysts is listed in Table 1 . After converting the weight percentages to atomic ratios, the results are close to the nominal ratios of Mn, Ce, Nb, and Ti for the two catalysts. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 (a). All the diffraction peaks can be assigned to rutile TiO2 (JCPDS 21-1272) and cubic fluorite CeO2 (JCPDS 43-1002) in both patterns. No Mn-containing or Nb-containing species were detected, which suggests that they are probably highly dispersed or in an amorphous state in the catalysts. The diffraction peaks originating from the TiO2 (1 0 1) and CeO2 (1 1 1) planes are magnified in Fig. 1(b). After Nb doping, the intensity of the CeO2 diffraction peak is decreased markedly and the peak position also shifted to a higher 2θ value. Nb ions have a smaller radius than that of the Ce ions [34]. This suggests that Nb could diffuse into the lattice of CeO2 and decrease its crystallinity. The SEM images in Fig. 2 show the morphologies of the catalysts. Fig. 2(a) and (c) reveal that the two catalysts possess similar morphologies, consisting of numerous agglomerates with sizes in the range of 0.4–1.3μm. Magnified images corresponding to Fig. 2(a) and (c) are presented in Fig. 2(b) and (d), respectively. There are aggregates on/near the agglomerates. These aggregates are much smaller in size than the agglomerates. During the preparation of the catalysts, the metal salts were converted to metal oxides. The oxide nanoparticles were sintered together with the adjacent ones and further agglomerated over the TiO2 support. Fig. S1 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the two catalysts. Both catalysts displayed type-IV isotherms with type-H3 hysteresis loops in the range of P/P0 >0.4, indicating they possess mesoporous structures, which are ascribed to the interstices between the particles [38–40]. The specific surface area and pore volumes of the two catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst possessed a specific surface area of 132m2 g−1, which was over 20% higher than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. The pore volumes of the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts were 0.29 and 0.30cm3 g−1, respectively. A large specific surface area is generally favorable for dispersing active components to create more active sites for catalytic reaction. 3.2 XPS results The chemical states of the elements in the two catalysts were investigated by XPS; the deconvoluted spectra are shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3(a) displays the Mn 2p spectra, which contain two main peaks consistent with the spin-orbit doublet of Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2. The Mn 2p 3/2 peak of each catalyst can be well fitted into three sub-peaks at 643–644, 641–642, and 640–641eV, which correspond to the 2p 3/2 peaks of Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+, respectively [11,18,30,41,42]. The relative atomic ratios of Mn4+/Mn n +, Mn3+/Mn n +, and Mn2+/Mn n + on the catalyst surfaces were estimated from the relative area of the sub-peaks, and the results are presented in Table 2 . With the addition of Nb, the Mn4+/Mn n + ratio decreases, while the Mn2+/Mn n + ratio increases, indicating a lower average valence state of Mn ions on the surface of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst compared with that on the Mn/Ce/Ti one. The Ce 3d spectra are presented in Fig. 3(b). According to the literature [43,44], the peaks marked as v (882.6eV), v” (888.7eV), v”’ (898.5eV), u (901.0eV), u” (907.6eV), and u”’ (916.7eV) are attributed to Ce4+ species, while those denoted as u 0 (898.8eV), u’ (903.5eV), v 0 (880.4eV), and v’ (885.0eV) are assigned to Ce3+ species. The ratios of Ce3+/Ce n + calculated from the XPS data were about 19.7% and 26.4% for the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts, respectively (Table 2). The Ce3+/Ce n + ratio of the catalyst increased notably after doping with Nb. The O 1s spectra of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3(c). These spectra can be fitted into three sub-peaks originating from three oxygen species: lattice oxygen (Oβ, 528.6–530.0eV), surface oxygen species (Oα, 531.4–532.0eV) such as surface-absorbed oxygen, and oxygen-containing surface groups (Oγ, 532.6–533.5eV) like carbonate and/or hydroxyl species [12,30,45–48]. Table 2 shows that the Oα/Otot. ratio of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst (14.3%) is considerably lower than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one (22.8%). Such a phenomenon reveals that the addition of Nb into the catalyst inhibits the formation of surface-labile oxygen, which has also been reported in the Nb-Ce systems [49]. It is widely accepted that Oα is more reactive than Oβ because of its higher mobility, which is probably favorable for the oxidation process [39]. Fig. 3(d) depicts the Nb 3d spectra obtained for the catalysts. According to the literature [34,50,51], the two peaks centered at 206.5 and 209.1eV were both attributed Nb5+ species, representing Nb5+ 3d 5/2 and Nb5+ 3d 3/2, respectively, with a spin-orbit splitting of 2.6eV. 3.3 Redox properties The redox properties of the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts were investigated via the H2-TPR method and the corresponding profiles are shown in Fig. 4 . Four different peaks were found in the reduction curve of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. According to the literature [12,13,52], the two reduction peaks with maxima around 240 and 335°C were attributed to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Mn3+ to Mn2+, respectively. The reduction peak centered at 666°C was assigned to the reduction of surface Ce4+ to Ce3+, and the fourth peak located around 884°C was consistent with the bulk reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [27,28]. For the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst, the two reduction peaks below 500°C, which displayed maxima at 235 and 315°C, were also ascribed to the reduction of Mn species, as described above. Two weak peaks in the range of 500–900°C and above 900°C should be related to the reduction of Ce and Nb ions. Previous research [33,53] has indicated that NbO x could be reduced at high temperature (above 700°C), overlapping with the reduction region of CeO2. It is therefore very difficult to distinguish the reduction peaks of NbO x and CeO2 in this curve. The H2 consumption of the catalysts was calculated; the results are given in Table 3 . In both regions of 0–500 and 500–1000°C, the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst consumed less H2 than the Mn/Ce/Ti one. Even after excluding the influence of atomic molar ratio, less oxygen was reduced by the Mn and Ce ions of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst. This implies that the average oxidation states of Mn and Ce in the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst are probably lower than those of the Mn and Ce in the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. O2-TPD experiments were performed to further evaluate the properties of the oxygen species in the catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. S2, multiple peaks of the oxygen signals are observed in the two curves because the systems are complex with multiple components. However, the O2 desorption peaks of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst were of lower intensity and shifted toward higher temperature compared with those of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst over the whole temperature range. This suggests that Nb doping strongly affects the amount and reactivity of oxygen species, which is in line with the H2-TPR results. 3.4 NH3-TPD measurements NH3-TPD experiments were performed to investigate the amount and strength of the acid sites on the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 , the curves of the two catalysts are roughly composed of two broad NH3 desorption bands centered at 100 and 200°C, which are originated from the desorption of NH3 on the weak Brønsted acid sites and strong Lewis acid sites, respectively [2,6,19]. At higher temperature (above 200°C), the desorbed products apart from NH3 were N2O and NO, which were generated from the reaction between the adsorbed NH3 and oxygen species in the catalysts. The desorption amounts of NH3, N2O, and NO are listed in Table 3. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst desorbed much more NH3 (1.95mmolg−1) than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst (1.48mmolg−1). This strongly suggests that more acid sites exist on the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst than on the Mn/Ce/Ti one. Moreover, the total amount of (2N2O+NO) over the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst (0.64mmolg−1) was less than that over the Mn/Ce/Ti one (0.78mmolg−1), which demonstrates that the Nb doping should favor inhibition of the oxidation of NH3 during the TPD process. 3.5 NH3 and NO oxidation Fig. 6 presents the catalytic oxidation activity of NH3 and the concentrations of the oxidation products (NO, NO2, and N2O) at different temperatures. NH3 began to be oxidized at 100°C on both catalysts. The two catalysts showed quite similar NH3 oxidation activity from 100 to 150°C, and they both reached 100% NH3 conversion at 250°C. However, the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst exhibited slightly higher NH3 conversion than the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst at 150–250°C. Comparing the product concentrations shown in Fig. 6(b), it is found that the NH3 oxidation products of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst have lower concentrations of NO, NO2, and N2O compared with those of the Mn/Ce/Ti ones; that is, the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst displays high selectivity for N2 in the NH3 oxidation process. Thus, it is suggested that the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst has lower NH3 oxidation ability than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, which suppresses the formation of NO, NO2, and N2O. The NO oxidation conversion over the two catalysts is plotted as a function of temperature in Fig. 7 . The main difference in the activities of the two catalysts appears in the temperature range of 150–275°C, in which the NO oxidative conversion of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst is slightly higher than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one. Both catalysts display their highest activity of 82% NO oxidative conversion at 300°C and then their activities follow the thermodynamic equilibrium line. 3.6 Catalytic performance As shown in Fig. 8 , the SCR performance of the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts are evaluated from 25 to 300°C, with a GHSV of 180 000h−1. The NO conversion of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst initially increased with temperature, reaching the highest NO conversion of 96% at 200°C, and then decreased to 83% at 300°C. In contrast, the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst showed its highest NO conversion of close to 100% at 150°C and maintains a high conversion of >98% in the whole temperature range. Even at low temperature (below 150°C), the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst exhibited higher NO conversion at every tested temperature. Fig. 8(b) depicts the NH3 conversion during the SCR reaction. The NH3 conversion of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst was higher than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one below 200°C and both catalysts achieved 100% NH3 conversion above 200°C. In addition, the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst exhibited obviously higher N2 selectivity, and maintained very high N2 selectivity of >90% below 250°C. A major drawback of Mn-based catalysts in low-temperature SCR is that their outstanding oxidative activity promotes the generation of NO2 and N2O, which limits their N2 selectivity in SCR processes [3,7,54]. The inset in Fig. 8(c) displays the NO2 and N2O concentrations during the activity tests. These results confirm that very low concentrations of both NO2 and N2O are generated over the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst, while relatively large amounts of NO2 and N2O are produced over the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, resulting in its poor N2 selectivity. 3.7 Long-term catalytic activity and catalyst regeneration The long-term reaction stability and effects of H2O and SO2 on the catalytic activity of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst were investigated at 175°C. As shown in Fig. 9 , the catalyst displayed satisfactory catalytic activity (∼100%) during 12h of continuous reaction. When 5 vol.% H2O was added to the gas flow, the catalytic activity immediately decreased to 90% and then slowly to ∼85% over the following 5h. When H2O was removed from the gas flow, the activity rapidly returned to 100% conversion. This can be explained by the competitive adsorption between NH3/NO x and H2O on the active sites leading to H2O having an inhibiting effect on the low-temperature SCR reaction [29,39]. When 5 vol.% H2O and 100ppm SO2 were introduced into the gas flow simultaneously, the catalytic activity decreased to 8% over 5h and barely recovered even after the removal of H2O and SO2. This indicates that severe poisoning of the catalyst occurred under the SO2-containing wet atmosphere. In the atmosphere with O2 and H2O, SO2 reacts with NH3 to form (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4, which deposit on the catalyst surface, resulting in its deactivation [3]. The depositing sulfates would not decompose at a low temperature such as 175°C, but can be easily washed away with water. Therefore, a simple regeneration method for the poisoned catalyst was to wash it with deionized water and then dry it at 110°C for 2h. After this regeneration process, the activity of the catalyst recovered to 92% and remained at 90% over the following 12h. However, some Mn- and Ce-containing sulfate species are generated in presence of SO2 and H2O, which are not easy to remove by washing the catalyst with water [39]. 4 Discussion 4.1 Influence of Nb doping on the other catalyst components The XRD and XPS results indicated that some of the Nb ions diffused into the CeO2 lattice, decreasing the crystallinity of CeO2 and increasing the Ce3+/(Ce3++ Ce4+) ratio in the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst. Similar results have been also reported over the Nb-Ce system in the literature [32,34,49]. The Mn species were also markedly influenced by Nb addition. The XPS results revealed that the average valence state of Mn ions at the surface of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst was decreased compared with that of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. The H2-TPR results showed that the presence of Nb in the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst decreased the oxidation ability of the Mn species [33]. Casapu et al. [22] used the X-ray absorption fine structure method to prove that the interaction between Mn and Nb species would lead to a lower average valence state of Mn ions in an MnO x -CeO2 catalyst. In their studies, Nb addition resulted in the partial reduction of nearly half of the Mn species. They also calcined their catalysts at higher temperatures (600, 800, and 1000°C) and identified a phase structure of MnNb2O6, which was also evidence for an interaction between Mn- and Nb-related species. Moreover, NbO x could act as a solid acid to provide more acid sites together with the TiO2 support [51]. 4.2 Analysis of catalytic activity The results of the activity tests presented in Section 3 revealed that the addition of Nb could remarkably increase the SCR performance of the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst, in terms of both NO conversion and N2 selectivity, even though NbO x itself does not show any NH3-SCR activity below 400°C [22,33]. According to the literature [3,27,55], the SCR reaction over Mn-based catalysts usually follows the Eley–Rideal (E-R) and/or Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanisms, in which acid sites play a key role in adsorbing and activating NH3 molecules. In the E-R mechanism, NH3 adsorbs onto the catalyst surface first and then it is dehydrogenated to generate surface-adsorbed NH2, which can further react with gaseous NO to yield N2 and H2O with surface-adsorbed NH2NO as an intermediate. In the L-H mechanism, NH3 molecules are also adsorbed on the catalyst surface, but react with surface NO2 − species on adjacent sites to form NH4NO2, then decompose to N2 and H2O. The NH3-TPD results in the present work indicated that both types of acid sites were strengthened by the addition of Nb to the Mn/Ce/Ti system. The SCR activity of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst could therefore be enhanced according to either of the reaction mechanisms from the aspect of surface acidity. Regarding NO oxidation, it is well recognized that Mn4+ is more active than Mn3+ and Mn2+, and Oα is a kind of active oxygen species that can promote the oxidation of NO to NO2 [5,11,18]. The lower Mn4+/Mn n + and Oα/Otot ratios of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst than those of the Mn/Ce/Ti ones should have resulted in inferior NO oxidation activity. However, the Ce3+/Ce n + ratio of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst was higher than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one. A higher Ce3+/Ce n + ratio in the catalyst could generate a charge imbalance, oxygen vacancies, and unsaturated chemical bonds on its surface to facilitate oxidation of NO to NO2 [11,19,30,40,49]. Under the dual effects of these two factors, the NO oxidation ability of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst was only slightly higher than that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one, as shown in Fig. 7. It is accepted that a NO:NO2 ratio of unity is most effective in NO x reduction because of the “fast SCR route” at low temperatures (<250°C) [56]. Higher NO oxidation activity can therefore promote the “fast SCR reaction” over the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst, also leading to higher SCR activity at low temperatures. 4.3 Analysis of N2 selectivity Concerning N2 selectivity, it has been illustrated that the NH3 oxidation ability of a catalyst affects its N2 selectivity in the NH3-SCR process [2,23,33,41]. According to Eq. (3), the formation of N2O and NO2 can markedly decrease the N2 selectivity. The NH3-TPD experiments without oxygen in the gas flow revealed that the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst had a lower oxidative activity for NH3 than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5, less NO and N2O were generated from the NH3-TPD process over the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst, although it obviously adsorbed more NH3 than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst. In NH3 oxidation with gas-phase O2, the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst displayed lower NH3 conversion than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst in the range of 150–250°C. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst also produced a smaller total amount of oxidative products (NO, NO2, and N2O) over the whole temperature range. The different Oα/Otot. ratios between the Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts should be responsible for the above tendency because of the strong oxidative activity of Oα. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst had a lower content of Oα than the Mn/Ce/Ti one, resulting in its limited NH3 oxidation activity in both the absence and presence of gas-phase O2. From another perspective, the NH3 molecules tended to adsorb on the Nb-related sites, so they were able to avoid reaction with the oxygen species in the catalyst. Above all, the generation of NO2 and N2O over the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst was restrained during the NH3-SCR process because of its lower oxidative ability for NH3 than that of the catalyst without Nb [2,3]. 5 Conclusion In this work, the effects of Nb addition to the Mn/Ce/Ti system on its performance as a catalyst in the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction were studied. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst showed higher catalytic activity and higher N2 selectivity than the Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst over the whole investigated temperature range. Nb doping increased the specific surface area and strengthened the acid sites of the catalyst. NO oxidation was also promoted by Nb doping, while the NH3 oxidation ability of the catalyst was restrained, which were both beneficial for the NH3-SCR performance of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst. The Nb-doped catalyst also showed favorable stability in a long-term reaction process. The inhibiting effect of H2O in the long-term test was reversible, and the SO2 and H2O poisoning effect could be largely suppressed by washing with water. coredata.dc:description: Mn/Ce/Ti and Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalysts were synthesized using a precipitation method and their catalytic activities for NO selective reduction with NH3 at low temperatures were evaluated. Nb doping not only improved the activity of the catalyst over a wide temperature range but also restricted the generation of NO2 and N2O. The Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst displayed 100% NO conversion from 150 to 250°C and >90% N2 selectivity below 250°C. The specific surface area of the catalyst was increased and its surface acidity was strengthened after Nb doping. Moreover, Nb doping increased the NO oxidation ability and lowered the NH3 oxidation activity of the catalyst. All the above factors contributed to enhancing the overall NH3-SCR performance of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst compared with that of the Mn/Ce/Ti one. The long-term stability and resistance to H2O and SO2 of the Mn/Ce/Nb/Ti catalyst were also evaluated.
coredata.dc:title: Nb-modified Mn/Ce/Ti catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 at low temperature
